qas.question: In which direction does the groove in a normal disc run?
How is sound encoded on a commercial disc?
Does it matter at which speed a disc is spun?

context: The normal commercial disc is engraved with two sound-bearing concentric spiral grooves, one on each side, running from the <a0_0>outside edge towards the center<a0_0/>. The last part of the spiral meets an earlier part to form a circle. The sound is encoded <a1_0>by fine variations<a1_0/> in the edges of the groove that cause a stylus (needle) placed in it to vibrate at acoustic frequencies when the disc is rotated at the <a2_0>correct speed<a2_0/>. Generally, the outer and inner parts of the groove bear <a3_0>no<a3_0/> intended sound (an exception is Split Enz's Mental Notes).
